questions.text: What is the fixative used in taking a PAP smear?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

95% ethyl alcohol

Highyeild:

PAP smear testing is a screening test for cervical cancer. Prerequisites The ideal time is around ovulation. Should be done before vaginal examination. The patient should not be menstruating during the pap testing. Lubricants should not be used. The patient should not have had intercourse in the last 24 hours.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false. The most common fixative used in PAP smear is 95% ethyl alcohol.

questions.text: According to WHO 2010 lower reference values of normal semen morphology should at least be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

0.04

Highyeild:

WHO criteria for semen analysis: Volume 1.5ml pH 7.2 – 7.8 Sperm concentration >/= 15 million/ml Total sperm count >/=39 million per ejaculate Motility >/= 40% (32% progressive motility) Normal morphology 4% (strict criteria) Vitality >/= 58% WBC < 1 million /ml Viscosity < 3 (scale 0 – 4)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are false.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: The below instruments are used for which of the following procedure:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PAP smear

Highyeild:

PAP smear testing is a screening test for cervical cancer. Prerequisites The ideal time is around ovulation. Should be done before the vaginal examination. The patient should not be menstruating during the pap testing. Lubricants should not be used. The patient should not have had intercourse in the last 24 hours.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are false. The image shows Koplin's jar, Ayre’s spatula and the endocervical brush used in the PAP smear test.

Extraedge:

Time for initiation – 21 years (regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse). 21 – 29 years – every 3 years 30 – 65 years – every 5 years (PAP + HPV) Age to stop having cervical cancer screening – 65 years (If suspicious PAP, screen till 75 years) HIV-positive female – Annual check-up until 3 consecutive negative tests, then every 3 years for life.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Arrange the steps of PAP smear testing in a correct sequence: Take the sample Fix the smear Make a smear on a slide Retract the posterior vaginal wall Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4-1-3-2

Highyeild:

The procedure of PAP smear testing: The patient is put in a dorsal Separate the labia and introduce Cusco’s self-retaining speculum. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush . Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is fixed immediately with 95% ethyl alcohol. Stained with PAP stain.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and D are false.

questions.text: Instruments used in the Caesarean section are: Green Armitage forceps Allis forceps Shirodkar’s clamp Doyen’s retractor Cusco’s speculum Bard parker handle Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2, 4 and 6 are correct

Highyeild:

Caesarean section is an operative procedure in which the fetuses are delivered through an incision on the abdominal and uterine walls. Green Armitage It is used as a hemostat in caesarean sections. Alli’s forceps – It is identified by the distal blades and a tip that has teeth that do not oppose each other. A lock is present in the proximal part. In LSCS, Alli’s forceps are used to catch hold of the margins and angles of the uterine flaps after the delivery of the baby in settings where the green Armitage hemostatic clamp is not available. Doyen’s retractor It is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder to facilitate better exposure of the lower uterine segment during the cesarean section. BP (Bard-Parker) blade For abdominal incisions, blade no – 22 is used commonly.\ Other uses – Incision of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, cutting the clamped pedicles and performing sharp dissections.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and C are false.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Quadruple test?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inhibin B

Highyeild:

The components of the Quadruple test are: MSAFP (maternal serum AFP) hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) Unconjugated estradiol Inhibin A

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are included.

Extraedge:

Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 NTDs or abdominal wall defects MSAFP Low Low High β hCG High Low Normal Unconjugated estradiol Low Low Normal Inhibin A High Normal / Low Normal

questions.text: An 18-year-old presents with ambiguous genitalia with 5 alpha reductase deficiencies. This condition is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Male pseudo hermaphroditism

Highyeild:

Male pseudohermaphroditism is associated with male gonads and female external genitalia. 5 alpha reductase enzyme converts testosterone into DHT (Dihydrotestosterone) which is capable of acting on the peripheral tissues to produce male phenotype. The absence of this enzyme leads to the female phenotype.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: The unicornuate uterus can be identified by which of the following investigations? Laparoscopy X-Ray Falloscopy HSG Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A & D are true

Highyeild:

Unicornuate uterus The uterus and fallopian tube will be formed by one Mullerian duct due to the developmental arrest of the other Mullerian Investigations: The first evaluation is through USG. Saline infusion sonography (SIS) can be used as a screening tool for cavity evaluation as well. HSG – Shows fusiform-shaped endometrial cavity, tapering at the apex and draining into a single fallopian tube. Hysteroscopic, laparoscopy – Invasive, reserved for complicated mullerian anomalies. MR imaging may be used.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are false. Faloscopy - Used for evaluation of Fallopian tubes. X-ray – Cannot be used to diagnose mullerian anomalies.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: An antennal USG of a 19-week pregnant female is given below. Identify the likely congenital abnormality:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anencephaly The given image shows open defects in the calvaria suggesting a diagnosis of anencephaly.

Highyeild:

Anencephaly is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects (detected as early as 10 – 11 weeks of gestation). U SG signs in anencephaly: Frog eye sign – Due to the absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits resemble the face of a Shower cap sign – The absence of the cranium could lead to the protrusion of a disorganised mass of brain tissue. This resembles a shower cap giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.

Table:

#MANTRA Anencephaly Anencephaly is fetal neural tube defects, Resulting from failure of neural tube to close at the base of skull Foetus develop without part of brain or Skull but is usually born with part of its cerebral trunk, brainstem. Anencephaly most often leads to death in days or weeks Mnemonic: " 8F " First Trimester diagnosis (usg) Fatal NTD Face Presentation (m/c resentation) Female Foetus (70% cases) False Date: preterm or post term Frog Eyes Fluid Excess (polyhydramnios) False(pseudo) Shoulder Dystocia Symptoms: No bones on the back of the head Missing bones on front & sides of head Large areas of brain missing Folding of ears Split in roof of the mouth (cleft palate) Congenital heart defects Folic acid before and during early pregnancy can help prevent neural tube defects, There is no known treatment for anencephaly.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation is found to have high blood pressure and urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia? Epigastric pain Blurred vision Headache Persistent pedal edema Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3 and 4

Highyeild:

Symptoms of impending eclampsia: Headache – usually over frontal and occipital regions. Visual disturbances – Due to spasms of retinal vessels. Epigastric or right upper quadrant pain – due to hepatocellular necrosis, ischaemia and edema that stretches the glisson’s capsule. Sudden and generalized or persistent edema. Disturbed sleep. Diminished urinary output.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and C are false.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the given clinical image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uterine prolapse In the given image, the whole of the both vaJginal walls and the uterus lie below the vaginal orifice. So it is grade 4 utero cervical prolapse .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- A. Uterine inversion – In a uterine inversion, the cervical os will not be seen as in this image. The lowermost part of the mass will be the uterine fundus. C. Cervical carcinoma – Mass lesions will present with fungating, cauliflower or punctate hemorrhagic lesions. D. Fibroid polyps – They are leiomyomas that present as polyps. Cervical fibroid polyps can be easily identified as the cervix is high up in its normal anatomical position unlike in the given image.

Table:

#MANTRA Classification of Prolapse Anterior Vaginal Wall: Upper Two-Thirds-Cystocele. }Cystourethrocele Lower One-Third-Urethrocele Posterior Vaginal Wall: Upper One-Third-Enterocele (Pouch of Douglas Hernia) Lower Two-Thirds-Rectocele UTERINE DESCENT: 1° ↔Descent of the Cervix in the Vagina. 2° ↔Descent of the Cervix to the Introitus. 3° ↔ Descent of the Cervix outside the Introitus. Procidentia- All of the Uterus outside the Introitus Note the descent of the cervix which is accompanied by stretching of the ligaments and by supravaginal elongation of the cervix.

questions.text: A 26 years old female who has 2 kids delivered by normal vaginal delivery presents to the hospital with dull aching pain over the abdomen with irregular menses. On P/V examination, a mass is felt in the posterior fornix. USG revealed a clear 5 X 5 cm ovarian cyst. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Follow up after 6 weeks In the given clinical vignette, a clear ovarian cyst of 5 X 5 cm is present. A clear ovarian cyst with minimal symptoms and less than 7 cm in a woman of reproductive age is most likely a functional cyst. The next best step is to follow up after 6 weeks and perform a repeat USG.

Highyeild:

Conservative management of ovarian cysts is done if the following criteria are met: Childbearing age Asymptomatic Unilocular Unilateral Less than 7cm

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are false.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the active management of the third stage of labour?

options.label: D
options.text: Uterotonics after delivery of the placenta

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Early cord clamping cord clamping is not a part of AMTSL; rather delayed cord clamping is done in AMTSL.

Highyeild:

Active management of the third stage of labour – recommended by WHO: Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (oxytocin) – within 1 minute Oxytocin 10 U is given IM or IV. Delayed cord clamping. Controlled cord traction. Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Uterinassage is not recommended but can be done.

Table:

#MANTRA 3 rd Stage of Labor: Active vs. Expectant Management Active Management Expectant Management • Prophylactic uterotonic medication • Early umbilical cord clamping • Delivery of the placenta by gentle, controlled traction • Uterine massage ● Delayed umbilical cord clamping and cutting (e.g. after pulsations cease) ● Delivery of placenta once signs of placental separation occur and delivers spontaneously

questions.text: Which of the following will not cause secondary amenorrhoea?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Kallman syndrome

Highyeild:

Kallman syndrome is hypothalamic hypogonadism . It causes primary amenorrhoea. Secondary amenorrhoea is the absence of menses for more than 3 months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or women who had irregular menstrual cycles. Asherman’s syndrome, Sheehan’s syndrome and Turner’s syndrome are the causes of secondary amenorrhoea.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false.

Table:

#MANTRA Kallman Syndrome X-linked recessive mutation in the KAL gene Codes of an adhesion molecule → results in lack of migration of GNRH neurons from the olfactory placcode Characteristics Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism Anosmia Midline facial defects Occasional renal agenesis Absence of pubertal development Primary amenorrhea Treatment: GNRH pulsing hCG/FSH Testosterone Oestrogen/progesterone Essential Supplements

questions.text: Which of the following is the best measure of ovarian reserve?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti Mullerian hormone

Highyeild:

AMH is the best marker of ovarian reserve. It is secreted by the granulosa cells. Functions of AMH: In males, secreted by the Sertoli cells inhibit the development of the Mullerian In females, secreted by granulosa cells and helps in follicular development and oocyte maturation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

The levels of AMH vary minimally across the cycle and they strongly correlate with the number of ovarian primordial follicles. So, AMH is the best predictor for measuring ovarian reserve. Normal – 2 to 6.8 ng/mL. Poor ovarian reserve - < 1 ng/mL. PCOD and hyperstimulation syndrome > 10ng/mL.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms are seen in endometriosis? The levels of AMH vary minimally across the cycle and they strongly correlate with the number of ovarian primordial follicles. So, AMH is the best predictor for measuring ovarian reserve. Normal – 2 to 6.8 ng/mL. Poor ovarian reserve - < 1 ng/mL. PCOD and hyperstimulation syndrome > 10ng/mL. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 3, 4

Highyeild:

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. Clinical features of endometriosis: Dysmenorrhoea Irregular bleeding Infertility Lower abdominal pain Pain during defecation or urination Constipation or diarrhoea

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and C are false.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: What is the normal uterocervical length?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

7cm The normal uterocervical length is 7 cm.

Highyeild:

Uterine corpus 🡪 5cm Isthmus 🡪5cm Cervix 🡪5cm Uterocervical length is measured by Sims uterine sound.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vulval carcinoma

Highyeild:

Most common site of vulval cancer is labia majora > clitoris > labia minora. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vulval cancer. Clinical features – Itching, plaque/ulcer, abnormal bleeding.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Vulval Haematoma – Collection of blood in the vulval region. Seen as tense swelling at the vulva which becomes dusky and purple in color. Bartholin’s cyst – Caused by obstruction of the Bartholin duct. Presents as painful, cystic swelling. Condyloma acuminata – Caused by infection with HPV 6 and 11. The verrucous growth may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 – B, 2 – A, 3 – D, 4 – C

Highyeild:

Sheehan’s syndrome/pituitary apoplexy – It is the hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it’s called Sheehan’s syndrome. Lab markers – Low FSH, low LH, Low estradiol.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B, C and D are false. Asherman’s syndrome – It is the presence of uterine synechiae due to the destruction of large areas of the endometrium. Lab markers – Normal FSH, Normal LH, Normal estradiol. PCOS – High LH, low FSH, low estradiol. Premature ovarian failure or premature menopause – Development of menopause before the age of 40 years. Lab markers - High FSH, High LH, Low estradiol

#MANTRA

questions.text: Which of the following complications is specific for monochorionic twins?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome

Highyeild:

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. In TTTS, the placental arteries and veins of two twins are connected through Occurs when monozygotic twinning results in two amniotic sacs and a common surrounding chorion. In those with significant pressure gradients, a shunt will develop between fetuses. This chronic feto fetal transfusion results in twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Neural tube defects are associated with folic acid deficiency. Polyhydramnios and NTDs can be seen in any pregnancy and are more common in pregnancies associated with diabetes mellitus.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Match the following syndromes with their respective karyotype:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 – C, 2 – B, 3 – D, 4 – A Turner’s syndrome – 45 + XO Sweyer’s syndrome – 46 + XY Androgen insensitivity syndrome – 46 + XY MRKH syndrome – 46 + XX

Highyeild:

Turner’s syndrome – Chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy X Features – Amenorrhoea, short stature, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, widely spaced nipples and lack of secondary sexual characters Sweyer’s syndrome – Pure gonadal dysgenesis due to the mutation of the SRY Features: Normal prepubertal female phenotype – Absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characters Normal mullerian system development – Due to the absence of AMH Female external genitalia Presence of dysgenetic testes that cannot produce AMH or sex hormones Androgen insensitivity syndrome: 46 + XY karyotype but the defective response of androgen receptors to androgens Primary amenorrhoea Normally developed breast -due to conversion of excess androgens to estrogen Underdeveloped ectopic Absence of uterus and cervix – due to AMH production MRKH syndrome (Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser) 46 + XX, Mullerian Ovaries are present Uterus, cervix – The upper 2/3 rd of the vagina is absent but the lower 1/3 rd is present as it develops from the urogenital sinus

Table:

#MANTRA
